subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie

------=_NextPart_000_0054_01C9D189.144B1740
Content-Type: text/plain;

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Or disprove, I should say.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: April A=
bercrombie 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 4:0=
3 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON






  OK=
...I did my test with a 4.43 MB wav file.

  I experienced no noticeable lo=
ss, and the file was the same size before and after being emailed.

  That =
still doesn't prove that maybe in some situations loss is possible.

  But =
again, like RJ, I have never experienced it myself.

    ----- Original Mes=
sage ----- 
    From: Rj 
    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
    Sent: Sunday=
, May 10, 2009 3:35 PM
    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTE=
NTION JON


          A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes=
 (and their bits) in the file.  If the file's content integrity is changed,=
 that is, by definition, changing the bytes.  If the bytes in there are not=
 changed, then that integrity has not changed.

          It is possible to=
 mess with other things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or its own=
ership) but this does not effect the contents, and so would not affect that=
 integrity, or the sound of the file (assuming you could read it at all aft=
er changing the ownership, or the suffix, etc).

          When you do your=
 tests, if you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would recommend at least=
 checking the file sizes.  If they are identical, there is a very high prob=
ability that the content has not changed.




          --- On Sun, 5/10/09=
, April Abercrombie <april@...> wrote:


         =
   From: April Abercrombie <april@...>
           =
 Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
            To: =
EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
            Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:28 PM



=
            Admittedly I do not know much about bit-level comparisons, what=
 they can or can't show so I will have to leave that to you. I have doubts =
because I worry once a file's integrity has been messed with, I wonder that=
 even though the bits match, maybe that doesn't mean they are the same qual=
ity as the original. I really don't know though what is possible or impossi=
ble when it comes to this area.

            "It is probably possible to se=
t up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My =
tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we=
 can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment wou=
ld be very unusual."

            The problem I have is that not just from =
Jon, but I have heard it from other people, and a professional and they all=
 said that loss is possible. From all that, my conclusion was that maybe in=
 some cases loss was possible.

            However, your arguments do put =
doubt back into my mind, which pisses me off, because I had originally argu=
ed feverishly for no loss, then I heard different from different sources an=
d decided to do what I thought was the right thing by contacting a third pa=
rty professional. So after all that, I decided I was licked and had to eat =
crow.

            Now I am back at square one, from the other side LOL!!! =
Computer people have been wrong in the past.


            "It is probably =
possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio com=
pression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test =
your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an =
attachment would be very unusual."

            I have not tested it from m=
y computer, as I haven't had any problems with loss. I would really like to=
 have Jon work with us on this, because he was the original person who told=
 me I was wrong.

            But I will test it from my side. I will send =
a wav file to one of my other addresses. Then I will download and compare. =
If I think I hear a difference, then maybe I can have you do a bit-level co=
mparison on the files.

            Either way, I am going to get to the bo=
ttom of this.



              ----- Original Message ----- 
              =
From: Rj 
              To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
              Sent: S=
unday, May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploa=
ding rules-ATTENTION JON


                    Yes you can tell loss of qua=
lity by a bit-level comparison.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, tha=
t is later interpreted by an audio player.  Two files with the exact same c=
ontents, whether they are audio or image or a dababase or an exe, are indis=
tinguishable from each other.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to =
a new file, and the contents of the other to a new file, and asked you whic=
h file each came from, there would be no way to tell.  Even the audio playe=
r could not tell.  The data is identical, and so the sound (or the picture,=
 etc) would be identical.

                    Yes I did listen to the resu=
lts, but that is not the best test (they sounded identical, but that is a s=
ubjective opinion).  The real test is compring the contents.  Identical con=
tents means indentical data, means identical audio.

                    It=
 is probably possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lo=
ssy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me =
to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compres=
sion from an attachment would be very unusual.


                    --- On=
 Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wro=
te:


                      From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh os=
tresearch. com>
                      Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading=
 rules-ATTENTION JON
                      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
   =
                   Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



                 =
     I have not personally experienced the loss myself. Jon from this list =
is the one who originally told me about it. I have also heard of it happeni=
ng to a few other people. After my conversation with Jon, I talked to a com=
puter professional, and he told me that you can experience loss in attached=
 files.

                      I don't know if you would be able to tell lo=
ss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level comparison. Just because th=
e data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is perfect.

            =
          Did you listen to the before and after results?

                =
      Jon-Please relay your experience with the loss of quality on emailed =
files.


                        ----- Original Message ----- 
            =
            From: Rj 
                        To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com =

                        Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
               =
         Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


                    =
          I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just did some t=
ests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allowing c=
ompression, and once turning it off.   I was able to verify that one was co=
mpressed and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at Yahoo.=
 Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of the origi=
nal, and the ones sent around email.  They were all identical, which indica=
tes lossless compression.

                              If you have a file=
 you'd like me to test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take someone's=
 word for how your server's work, without testing them yourself.



       =
                       --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercr=
ombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                From: Ap=
ril Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                    =
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                   =
             To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                D=
ate: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



                                For =
executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the compression duri=
ng email is not loss less. 

                                I used to thin=
k as you do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file would not loose a=
nything. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I learned that=
 I was wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first place is tha=
t when I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it in very smal=
l segments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of transfer. But=
 because of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

             =
                   Now it may be in some cases, depending on the servers or=
 what have you that the file goes through, that the loss may be less or mor=
e. But once the attachment is downloaded, the quality has been found to be =
less then the original wav.

                                Again though y=
ou can only really tell when the wav file is large.

                      =
          ----- Original Message ----- 
                                Fro=
m: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
      =
                          Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
              =
                  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


           =
                     The kind of compression that occurs during an email at=
tachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without losing inform=
ation.  For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, and I sent it o=
ver email, it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the resultin=
g exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed on the other s=
ide.

                                This kind of compression does things =
like looking for common patterns in the file, and replacing them with a tok=
en.  A rough example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 tim=
es, it could replace all the occurances with say $HN1.  And also write a li=
ttle dictionary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

    =
                            When the file gets to its destination it can be=
 uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "Howdy Neighbor=
".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it only needed 4, =
plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

                                So=
me formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending on the level of=
 compression, some level of data is lost, and so cannot be recovered or rec=
onstructed later.

                                Rick



                =
                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh=
 ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                From: April Abe=
rcrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                           =
     Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                          =
      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Su=
nday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                                Another thi=
ng:

                                I recently found this out. When you em=
ail a file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the email filtering =
process will actually compress the file automatically.

                   =
             So even if you have attached a wav. file, it will loose resolu=
tion over the email process. It will not sound exactly the same as the orig=
inal wav. file. How much it differs depends on the size of the file you are=
 attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound much different.

    =
                            The only exception to this is if the wav. file =
is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It has to be pre=
tty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the threshold).=


                                The best way to share files over the inte=
rnet if you want them as close to the original as possible is to upload the=
m directly to a website.

                                ----- Original Me=
ssage ----- 
                                From: Rj 
                    =
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                S=
ent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                                Subject:=
 Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                                Pixe=
lization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a pictu=
re of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixelization to th=
e picture.  Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flowers there at=
 all.  You would see a lot of colored blocks.

                            =
    Or in the other direction, imagine you are looking at a competely rando=
mize bunch of pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truely random stat=
ic snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, you would again start to see colo=
red blocks.

                                What's happening is that it is=
 processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the average value o=
f that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area with the aver=
age.  In video processing, this would result in a field of multi-colored fl=
owers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish block, with no =
resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replace all the ran=
dom pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know befo=
rehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether your pixeli=
zed image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with clouds, or a=
 random bunch of pixels.

                                It works the same=
 with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as speech, and replacin=
g frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farther you go, unt=
il you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same to random sta=
tic will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fluctuating square =
waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing=
 with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





                   =
             --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote=
:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.co=
m>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading ru=
les
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
          =
                      Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


               =
                 I always save the whole file in wav format then do my clip=
s as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

                        =
        As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos to say that i=
snt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of white noise. =
I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film, no recordin=
g done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all interesting.

    =
                            Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
           =
                     Misty

                                --- On Sun, 5/1=
0/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                                Fro=
m: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                                Subject: Re: [E=
VP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@ya=
hoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, =
11:47 AM


                                Be a bit careful of formats like=
 mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though.   While som=
e formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way it was recor=
ded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose some of the s=
onic details.  This may not be a big deal in music, where the audio is fair=
ly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources with a lot of noise (like e=
vps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (l=
ike white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

               =
                 So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, once you've alr=
eady formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  But mp3 is no=
t good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many false positives and m=
isinterpretations.

                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Mi=
sty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                                =
From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                                S=
ubject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                =
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, =
May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM


                                Thanks =3D)

      =
                           You will get the hang of it. Kristen is right th=
ats how you save it. For most softwares its under save as or export as. If =
you still have trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya out.

     =
                           Misty

                                --- On Su=
n, 5/10/09, SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:


              =
                  From: SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com>
           =
                     Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules

                      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com

        Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:14 AM


                             =
   Ok, Misty I'll take them out, this recording stuff is new to me.

      =

                                Misty

>
                <TR>
                  <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Yes you can tell =
loss of quality by a 
                    bit-level comparison.  An au=
dio file is just a file of 
                    bytes, that is later interp=
reted by an audio player.  
                    Two files with the exa=
ct same contents, whether they are 
                    audio or image or a=
 dababase or an exe, are 
                    indistinguishable from each o=
ther.  That is, if I 
                    copied the contents of one t=
o a new file, and the contents 
                    of the other to a new f=
ile, and asked you which file each 
                    came from, there wo=
uld be no way to tell.  Even the 
                    audio player cou=
ld not tell.  The data is identical, 
                    and so the s=
ound (or the picture, etc) would be 
                    identical.<BR><BR>=
Yes I did listen to the results, but that 
                    is not the b=
est test (they sounded identical, but that is a 
                    subjec=
tive opinion).  The real test is compring the 
                    con=
tents.  Identical contents means indentical data, 
                   =
 means identical audio.<BR><BR>It is probably possible to set 
            =
        up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio 
          =
          compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If 
   =
                 you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too.=
 
                    From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment=
 would 
                    be very unusual.<BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10=
/09, April 
                    Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombiegh ostr=
esearch. 
                    com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                  =

eard of

er my

         <TR>
                            <TD vAlign=3Dtop>I can't vouch fo=
r your computer or 
                              servers, but I just did s=
ome tests, and sent a 
                              2.1MB wav file from MS=
N to Yahoo and back, once 
                              allowing compressi=
on, and once turning it 
                              off.   I w=
as able to verify that one was 
                              compressed an=
d one was not, by checking the sizes 
                              when th=
ey arrived at Yahoo. Once they came back to 
                              =
MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of the 
                            =
  original, and the ones sent around email.  
                        =
      They were all identical, which indicates lossless 
                  =
            compression.<BR><BR>If you have a file you'd like 
            =
                  me to test for you, let me know.  But I 
           =
                   wouldn't take someone's word for how your server's 
    =
                          work, without testing them 
                     =
         yourself.<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09,

Myriad Pro">For

because of this,

ace=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>

<TBODY>

                              =
  <TD vAlign=3Dtop>The kind of compression that 
                          =
      occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": 
                   =
             it compress the file cleverly without losing 
                =
                information.  For example, if I had a 
               =
                 program in some .exe files, and I sent it over 
          =
                      email, it could compress it.  But if it 
       =
                         lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
 =
                               not execute again after it was uncompressed =
on 
                                the other side.<BR><BR>This kind of com=
pression 
                                does things like looking for comm=
on patterns in 
                                the file, and replacing the=
m with a token.  
                                A rough example woul=
d be if it found "Howdy 
                                Neighbor" in a fil=
e 20 times, it could replace 
                                all the occur=
ances with say $HN1.  And also 
                                write =
a little dictionary in there someplace 
                                tha=
t says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".<BR><BR>When the 
                          =
      file gets to its destination it can be 
                             =
   uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are 
                          =
      replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was 
                    =
            compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it 
                =
                only needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no 
         =
                       data.<BR><BR>Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
     =
                           are not lossless.  Depending on the level 
=
                                of compression, some level of data is lost,=
 and 
                                so cannot be recovered or reconstruct=
ed 
                                later.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- O=
n <B>Sun, 
                                5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
    =
                            <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
      =
                          com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                      =
          <BLOCKQUOTE 
                                style=3D"BORDER-LEFT=
: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid"><BR>From: 
                                Apri=
l Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh 
                                ostr=
esearch. com><BR>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] 
                               =
 File uploading rules<BR>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups 
                         =
       .com<BR>Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 
                         =
       AM<BR><BR>
                                <DIV id=3Dyiv819860743>
 =
                               <DIV id=3Dygrp-text>
                       =
         <P></P>

=3D"Myriad Pro">Another 
                                thing:</FONT></DIV=
>

                    =
            face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>

        =

   =

e=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>

                     =

                   =

            =

               =

                =
                different.</FONT></DIV>

V><FONT size=3D2 
                                face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FON=
T> </DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"=
Myriad Pro">The only 
                                exception to this is =
if the wav. file is small 
                                enough that the =
filtering process will ignore 
                                it. It has t=
o be pretty small though, like under 
                                1&nbs=
p;MB (I am not exactly sure of the 
                                thresho=
ld).</FONT></DIV>
                                <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
    =
                            face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
       =
                         <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">The best w=
ay

f you

        =
                        <TD vAlign=3Dtop><BR>Pixelization doesn't clean-up =

                                the data: it replaces it.  Imagine ta=
king a 
                                picture of a field of flowers, and =
beginning to 
                                add levels or pixelization to=
 the picture.  
                                Soon, you would not be=
 able to tell there were 
                                flowers there at =
all.  You would see a lot 
                                of colored =
blocks.<BR><BR>Or in the other 
                                direction, =
imagine you are looking at a 
                                competely ran=
domize bunch of pixes on your 
                                screen: a co=
mplete screen of truely random 
                                static snow=
.  Pixelizing this, after a 
                                while, yo=
u would again start to see colored 
                                blocks.=
<BR><BR>What's happening is that it is 
                                pro=
cessing an area of the image, taking (for 
                                =
instance) the average value of that entire area, 
                         =
       and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
                    =
            the average.  In video processing, this 
                 =
               would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
          =
                      being replaced by, for instance, a big 
             =
                   greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
          =
                      flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe 
      =
                          replace all the random pixels with another big 
 =
                               greyish-bluish block.  If you did not k=
now 
                                beforehand what the original picture w=
as, you 
                                couldn't tell whether your pixeliz=
ed image was 
                                really a field of flowers, a =
chevy, the sky with 
                                clouds, or a random bu=
nch of pixels.<BR><BR>It 
                                works the same wi=
th the sound files.  
                                Taking something=
 as complex as speech, and 
                                replacing frequ=
encies with their averages, loses 
                                the spee=
ch the farther you go, until you head 
                                stra=
nge fluctuating square waves.  Doing 
                                =
the same to random static will eventually 
                                =
produce the same thing.  And random 
                                f=
luctuating square waves can sound a bit like 
                             =
   speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing 
                      =
          with each other what you thing they 'sound 
                     =
           like'.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                  =
              5/10/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
                    =
            yahoo.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                              =
  <BLOCKQUOTE

    vAlign=3Dtop>
                                <DIV>I always save the wh=
ole file in wav format 
                                then do my clips as=
 mp3. Then I have the 
                                original for analysi=
s. </DIV>
                                <DIV> </DIV>
               =
                 <DIV>As far as pixelization of non sounds/white 
         =
                       noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by 
  =
                              them as well LOL. Water is a form of white 
 =
                               noise. I seem to remember some experiments d=
one 
                                with blank tapes/film, no recording&nb=
sp;done 
                                yet there were voices/images there=
. I find it 
                                all interesting.</DIV>
       =

From:

bject: Re:

unday, May

                                <DIV>
      =
                          <TABLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0=
>
                                <TBODY>
                                <=
TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Be a bit careful of fo=
rmats like 
                                mp3 if you are doing a detailed=
 analysis of the 
                                sounds though. &nbsp=
; While some formats 
                                (like wav) can store =
the audio very close to the 
                                way it was rec=
orded, formats like mp3 compress 
                                the file,=
 and in so doing lose some of the sonic 
                                de=
tails.  This may not be a big deal in 
                               =
 music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin 
                         =
       with.  But with sound sources with a lot of 
                  =
              noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any 
           =
                     real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
    =
                            noise) and make them start to sound like 
     =
                           speech.<BR><BR>So mp3 might be good for sharing =

                                the data, once you've already formed an op=
inion 
                                based on an analysis of the wav file=
.  But 
                                mp3 is not good as a medium fo=
r analysis.  
                                It can lead to many fals=
e positives and 
                                misinterpretations.<BR><BR=
